documents.content: “He's the worst clown ever.” “He's got the worst luck.” “But he's a fantastic kisser!” Whispers buzzed backstage minutes before they started filming the TV show. Distracted stagehands walked by, listening to their earpieces. I was listening to the gossip. “Did he go to clown college?” “He got kicked out.” “Maybe he wasn't funny enough.” “Maybe he was too unlucky!” The stagehands continued ignoring us, until I told the gossipers there was fresh cake in the waiting room. “That cake is for our guest,” one young stage manager said firmly, “and you will treat him with respect.” “It's the way of the world,” joked a comedy writer in a green suit. “No matter where you go, you've got to respect Bumbo.” There was a poster of Bumbo in the hall outside the studio. In it, he wore an enormous frown painted on his face, surrounded by brown greasepaint like an unshaven beard. His ugly face repulsed me (and fascinated me). But even the poster seemed sad, with his black clown's eyes staring helplessly below a torn hat. “Once he got in a cab, and the cab crashed,” the comedy writer continued. “So then he missed his flight to Miami. And then the airplane crashed!” “That's an urban legend,” said a blonde actress. She'd heard the same stories, but over the years she'd met actors who'd actually known Bumbo. “He's bad at math and he's a cheapskate, but he never crashed in a taxi.” She wasn't Bumbo's usual assistant, but they'd hired her to help suggest a circus. She was wearing a top hat, like a ringmaster, and a sparkly black costume. She seemed just as down on the clown as everyone else, even if she had heard that he was a terrific kisser. I was nervous about meeting real show people. It was just yesterday I'd received that frantic phone call about appearing on TV. The bank where I worked raised $10,000 to help poor children -- and they planned to donate it to Bumbo's favorite charity. As a special treat, Bumbo would receive the money on a local variety show that was broadcast to the entire state every Saturday night. I'd represent the bank, standing formally in a suit and tie, while Bumbo would slip, do a somersault, and pretend to drop the suitcase filled with money. They'd prepared green strips of paper that Bumbo would chase after comically, slipping and somersaulting all across the stage. At the end of the skit, I'd hold up a second suitcase -- the one filled with real money -- and Bumbo would sadly shrug his shoulders at the audience. At least, that's what we'd thought was going to happen ... “That's more money than I earned all year,” joked the blonde actress. Her name was Dusty, and she seemed both glamorous and gloomy, wearing heavy makeup hiding the signs of age on her face. She'd been dressed in a leotard for two hours, and her legs looked chilly. “I used to want to be rich and famous. Now I'd settle for just rich.” “Heck, I'd settle for a piece of Bumbo's cake,” said the comedy writer. “I hear it's pretty good.” The comedy writer was always laughing. He was confident and sharp, even while donning a green, pin stripe suit. “Heck, I'd settle for $10,000,” he added, though no one was laughing at his jokes. A few minutes ago when he'd showed up in his green suit, Dusty whispered a catty secret about the writer's wardrobe. In his bedroom closet hung six suits, each one a different shade of green. He thought they'd help people remember his name, which I found out later was -- coincidentally -- Mr. Green. “Stop jabbering,” the stage manager snapped. “The show starts in eight minutes.” Enormous lights pointed towards the empty stage next to us, as even more stagehands began clustering in the wings and behind cameras. He stared at me like he was studying an insect, and then asked “Are you the pie thrower?” No, I explained nervously, I'm from the bank. I hand Bumbo the suitcase of money. “And then you smash a pie into his face,” said the stage manager. “Didn't you read your script?” “Script?” I asked. I'd memorized a statement from the bank, but they hadn't said anything about a pie. “Ouch! Bumbo's not going to like that,” teased Mr. Green. The stage manager seemed irritated. Fighting back anger, he instructed: “Watch for my signal. When I smash my right hand into my left hand … smash the pie into Bumbo's face. Got it?” I nodded nervously. “Don't be scared,” Dusty said. “Bumbo's just like you and me. Except famous.” “And rich,” added Mr. Green. “Why don't you go and talk to him?” “Are you crazy?” Mr. Green answered. “Bumbo's afraid of people! He hides in his dressing room until show time!” Dusty assured me this was just another urban legend, as she pointed me toward the famous clown's dressing room. *			*			* Peeking around the corner, I saw that the hallway was empty. All the stagehands had gone to the stage, and the rest of the building looked deserted. But I wasn't sure I was allowed to be there -- even if Dusty said it was OK. Would the clown be frightened by a stranger visiting? Would I be frightened by the visiting clown? Soon my shoes were echoing down the white tile floor. For a moment I just stood outside his door, not sure if I should knock. I checked for the fussy stage manager, but there was no one around, so I took a deep breath, and rapped on the door. It suddenly swung open. I nearly jumped out of my skin. There was that enormous white frown, and cheeks covered with dark brown makeup. But the face didn't move. It just stared at me silently. Not sad, but bored. “Yes?” Bumbo asked. Classical music came from the room behind him. There was a thick Russian novel on a table next to a bottle of vodka. There were makeup dishes in front of the mirror, but the room was completely empty. Bumbo had arrived at the studio already in costume, and though I couldn't be sure, he'd apparently waited alone in his dressing room. “I'm supposed to smash a pie into your face,” I said. “I know,” said Bumbo. “I read the script.” He saw that I was staring at the thick book on his table, and smiled to himself. “Clowns pretend to be stupid,” he said. “But that’s us acting. We're actually very clever.” “Is it difficult to pretend you're stupid?” Bumbo glared back, but didn't speak for a moment. Then he said, “Clowns exist in our mind already.” And now he was really starting to freak me out ... *			*			* When I stepped out of Bumbo's room, a police officer grabbed me. “Come with me,” he commanded. “But I'm supposed to throw a pie!” “Not any more, you're not,” he said, and led me to two more police officers. Their hair was short, and their uniforms were black. They looked like they never smiled. “Take him upstairs,” the police officer commanded. “No, seriously! I'm supposed to throw a pie!” *			*			* In the back of the TV studio was a second floor conference room where the windows didn't open. It looked out over the parking lot, where I could see two police cars. In the back of the room was the fussy stage manager, insisting that the show had to go on. “I checked with your director,” one of the officers relayed, “and he can delay the taping for another half hour. “And besides,” he said, leaning his face towards the young man. “There's nothing to film. You don't have $10,000 to give to Bumbo. Because somebody stole it!” The stage manager had hidden the suitcase with the money backstage, along with the other suitcase filled with the little green strips of paper. He was going to hand the suitcase with the fake money to Bumbo, and then at the end of the skit, hand the second suitcase to Dusty, who would carry it out to me. But minutes before show time, he'd discovered that there was only one suitcase left. He was sure that he'd secretly tucked both of them into the backstage props closet, and no one knew they were there -- except the stage manager and Dusty. But I was a suspect too, because everyone assumed I'd been carefully watching the bank's money. But I hadn't! And now I'd created a lot of trouble. “Mr. Green knew the money was there, too,” said the stage manager. “He's worked here for years, so he'd know the suitcase had to be in the prop closet before filming. And he'd know it was full of money, since he wrote the skit himself.” “Maybe he needed it to buy more green suits” muttered Dusty. “Anyone else know where the cash was hidden?” asked the police officer. “Bumbo,” said the stage manager. “He always likes to know where his props are.” “And you,” added Bumbo, darkly from the door. We looked up to see him being led in. I expected them to say “trick or treat,” but instead of candy, one of us was going to jail. They frisked Bumbo and the rest of us, but nobody had $10,000 in their pockets. And then the police reviewed the few facts of the case. For the last hour, there'd been a cameraman standing by the prop closet who swore that no one had gone near it. And before that, his camera had been pointed towards the floor, which meant someone in the control booth could see the ground in front of the closet for the previous hour. Exactly one person had entered the closet -- zipping in and out in less than two seconds -- but unfortunately, they couldn't tell who. They'd caught a brief glimpse of a pant leg, but that was useless without the color of the pants, which they couldn't remember. “Heck, it could've been the clown, for all we know,” the policeman complained. “We have to film this show today!” the stage manager complained. But I'd already figured out who'd stolen the money.

original_metadata.reveal_text:
“It's not Mr. Green,” I said. “He only arrived at the studio a few minutes before the filming. By the time he'd gotten here, the suitcase had already been stolen!”
“And Bumbo doesn't have the suitcase,” I added. “I've seen his dressing room, and it's completely empty.”
Everyone looked around the room, genuinely impressed that I'd ruled out so many suspects.
“And I know Dusty didn't steal the money ... because she's not wearing pants! Think about it. There were two suitcases backstage, but only one of them had real money, while the other one had fake money. Yet the thief zipped out of the prop closet in just two seconds -- not enough time to open the suitcases and determine which one hid the real money. The thief had known that already. And the only person who knew which suitcase had the money was ...”
“The stage manager!” exclaimed Bumbo. Sure enough, the suitcase was stashed in the trunk of his car, and we'd be able to finish filming the show after all. A police car pulled up to the front of the building, and as the police moved in for the arrest, Bumbo whispered a suggestion to me about how to say goodbye to the guilty stage manager.
And so I smashed a pie into his face.

But even the poster seemed sad, with his black clown's eyes staring helplessly below a torn hat. “Once he got in a cab, and the cab crashed,” the comedy writer continued. “So then he missed his flight to Miami. And then the airplane crashed!” “That's an urban legend,” said a blonde actress. She'd heard the same stories, but over the years she'd met actors who'd actually known Bumbo. “He's bad at math and he's a cheapskate, but he never crashed in a taxi.” She wasn't Bumbo's usual assistant, but they'd hired her to help suggest a circus. She was wearing a top hat, like a ringmaster, and a sparkly black costume. She seemed just as down on the clown as everyone else, even if she had heard that he was a terrific kisser. I was nervous about meeting real show people. It was just yesterday I'd received that frantic phone call about appearing on TV. The bank where I worked raised $10,000 to help poor children -- and they planned to donate it to Bumbo's favorite charity. As a special treat, Bumbo would receive the money on a local variety show that was broadcast to the entire state every Saturday night. I'd represent the bank, standing formally in a suit and tie, while Bumbo would slip, do a somersault, and pretend to drop the suitcase filled with money. They'd prepared green strips of paper that Bumbo would chase after comically, slipping and somersaulting all across the stage. At the end of the skit, I'd hold up a second suitcase -- the one filled with real money -- and Bumbo would sadly shrug his shoulders at the audience. At least, that's what we'd thought was going to happen ... “That's more money than I earned all year,” joked the blonde actress. Her name was Dusty, and she seemed both glamorous and gloomy, wearing heavy makeup hiding the signs of age on her face. She'd been dressed in a leotard for two hours, and her legs looked chilly. “I used to want to be rich and famous. Now I'd settle for just rich.” “Heck, I'd settle for a piece of Bumbo's cake,” said the comedy writer. “I hear it's pretty good.” The comedy writer was always laughing. He was confident and sharp, even while donning a green, pin stripe suit. “Heck, I'd settle for $10,000,” he added, though no one was laughing at his jokes. A few minutes ago when he'd showed up in his green suit, Dusty whispered a catty secret about the writer's wardrobe. In his bedroom closet hung six suits, each one a different shade of green. He thought they'd help people remember his name, which I found out later was -- coincidentally -- Mr. Green. “Stop jabbering,” the stage manager snapped. “The show starts in eight minutes.” Enormous lights pointed towards the empty stage next to us, as even more stagehands began clustering in the wings and behind cameras. He stared at me like he was studying an insect, and then asked “Are you the pie thrower?” No, I explained nervously, I'm from the bank. I hand Bumbo the suitcase of money. “And then you smash a pie into his face,” said the stage manager. “Didn't you read your script?” “Script?” I asked. I'd memorized a statement from the bank, but they hadn't said anything about a pie. “Ouch! Bumbo's not going to like that,” teased Mr. Green. The stage manager seemed irritated. Fighting back anger, he instructed: “Watch for my signal. When I smash my right hand into my left hand … smash the pie into Bumbo's face. Got it?” I nodded nervously. “Don't be scared,” Dusty said. “Bumbo's just like you and me. Except famous.” “And rich,” added Mr. Green. “Why don't you go and talk to him?” “Are you crazy?” Mr. Green answered. “Bumbo's afraid of people! He hides in his dressing room until show time!” Dusty assured me this was just another urban legend, as she pointed me toward the famous clown's dressing room. *			*			* Peeking around the corner, I saw that the hallway was empty. All the stagehands had gone to the stage, and the rest of the building looked deserted. But I wasn't sure I was allowed to be there -- even if Dusty said it was OK. Would the clown be frightened by a stranger visiting? Would I be frightened by the visiting clown? Soon my shoes were echoing down the white tile floor. For a moment I just stood outside his door, not sure if I should knock. I checked for the fussy stage manager, but there was no one around, so I took a deep breath, and rapped on the door. It suddenly swung open. I nearly jumped out of my skin. There was that enormous white frown, and cheeks covered with dark brown makeup. But the face didn't move. It just stared at me silently. Not sad, but bored. “Yes?” Bumbo asked. Classical music came from the room behind him. There was a thick Russian novel on a table next to a bottle of vodka. There were makeup dishes in front of the mirror, but the room was completely empty. Bumbo had arrived at the studio already in costume, and though I couldn't be sure, he'd apparently waited alone in his dressing room. “I'm supposed to smash a pie into your face,” I said. “I know,” said Bumbo. “I read the script.” He saw that I was staring at the thick book on his table, and smiled to himself. “Clowns pretend to be stupid,” he said. “But that’s us acting. We're actually very clever.” “Is it difficult to pretend you're stupid?” Bumbo glared back, but didn't speak for a moment. Then he said, “Clowns exist in our mind already.” And now he was really starting to freak me out ... *			*			* When I stepped out of Bumbo's room, a police officer grabbed me. “Come with me,” he commanded. “But I'm supposed to throw a pie!” “Not any more, you're not,” he said, and led me to two more police officers. Their hair was short, and their uniforms were black. They looked like they never smiled. “Take him upstairs,” the police officer commanded. “No, seriously! I'm supposed to throw a pie!” *			*			* In the back of the TV studio was a second floor conference room where the windows didn't open. It looked out over the parking lot, where I could see two police cars. In the back of the room was the fussy stage manager, insisting that the show had to go on. “I checked with your director,” one of the officers relayed, “and he can delay the taping for another half hour. “And besides,” he said, leaning his face towards the young man. “There's nothing to film. You don't have $10,000 to give to Bumbo. Because somebody stole it!” The stage manager had hidden the suitcase with the money backstage, along with the other suitcase filled with the little green strips of paper. He was going to hand the suitcase with the fake money to Bumbo, and then at the end of the skit, hand the second suitcase to Dusty, who would carry it out to me. But minutes before show time, he'd discovered that there was only one suitcase left. He was sure that he'd secretly tucked both of them into the backstage props closet, and no one knew they were there -- except the stage manager and Dusty. But I was a suspect too, because everyone assumed I'd been carefully watching the bank's money. But I hadn't! And now I'd created a lot of trouble. “Mr. Green knew the money was there, too,” said the stage manager. “He's worked here for years, so he'd know the suitcase had to be in the prop closet before filming. And he'd know it was full of money, since he wrote the skit himself.” “Maybe he needed it to buy more green suits” muttered Dusty. “Anyone else know where the cash was hidden?” asked the police officer. “Bumbo,” said the stage manager. “He always likes to know where his props are.” “And you,” added Bumbo, darkly from the door. We looked up to see him being led in. I expected them to say “trick or treat,” but instead of candy, one of us was going to jail. They frisked Bumbo and the rest of us, but nobody had $10,000 in their pockets. And then the police reviewed the few facts of the case. For the last hour, there'd been a cameraman standing by the prop closet who swore that no one had gone near it. And before that, his camera had been pointed towards the floor, which meant someone in the control booth could see the ground in front of the closet for the previous hour. Exactly one person had entered the closet -- zipping in and out in less than two seconds -- but unfortunately, they couldn't tell who. They'd caught a brief glimpse of a pant leg, but that was useless without the color of the pants, which they couldn't remember. “Heck, it could've been the clown, for all we know,” the policeman complained. “We have to film this show today!” the stage manager complained. But I'd already figured out who'd stolen the money.
“It's not Mr. Green,” I said. “He only arrived at the studio a few minutes before the filming. By the time he'd gotten here, the suitcase had already been stolen!”
“And Bumbo doesn't have the suitcase,” I added. “I've seen his dressing room, and it's completely empty.”
Everyone looked around the room, genuinely impressed that I'd ruled out so many suspects.
“And I know Dusty didn't steal the money ... because she's not wearing pants! Think about it. There were two suitcases backstage, but only one of them had real money, while the other one had fake money. Yet the thief zipped out of the prop closet in just two seconds -- not enough time to open the suitcases and determine which one hid the real money. The thief had known that already. And the only person who knew which suitcase had the money was ...”
“The stage manager!” exclaimed Bumbo. Sure enough, the suitcase was stashed in the trunk of his car, and we'd be able to finish filming the show after all. A police car pulled up to the front of the building, and as the police moved in for the arrest, Bumbo whispered a suggestion to me about how to say goodbye to the guilty stage manager.
And so I smashed a pie into his face.

detection.solution:
<THOUGHT PROCESS>
1. Motive  
• The $10,000 is a tempting amount for anyone who is chronically under-paid at a TV studio.  
• Of all the characters, the stage manager is openly under pressure (“The show starts in eight minutes”, “We have to film this show today”) and is the one who keeps complaining that he must make everything work.  A sudden cash windfall would solve his problems.

2. Opportunity  
• The two suitcases were hidden by the stage manager himself in the prop closet.  
• Only the stage manager, Dusty, and (by hearsay) Bumbo knew that two identical suitcases were there.  
• The camera shows that only one person dashed into the closet (in less than two seconds) during the un-watched interval.  A person already positive which suitcase held the real cash could perform the theft that quickly; anyone else would need time to open both or weigh them.  
• The stage manager had legitimate reason to be moving around backstage and could approach the closet without raising suspicion.  
• Mr Green had not yet arrived; Bumbo was in his dressing room; the narrator was elsewhere; Dusty was in sight of others.

3. Physical evidence / alibis  
• Mr Green: arrived only minutes before air-time, after the money was known to be missing.  
• Dusty: wearing a leotard—no trousers.  The camera saw a trouser-leg.  
• Bumbo: dressing room searched, empty; frisked—no money.  No trousers matching the glimpse either (his costume covers the legs with clown pants).  
• Stage manager: when police finally look, the suitcase is in the trunk of his car.

4. Logical deduction  
• Only the thief knew in advance which identical case held the cash.  
• Only the stage manager had that privileged knowledge and the chance to plant the case in his car.  
• Therefore the stage manager must be the culprit.
</THOUGHT PROCESS>

<SUSPECTS>
Stage Manager, Dusty (assistant/ring-mistress), Mr. Green (comedy writer), Bumbo the Clown, Narrator (bank representative)
</SUSPECTS>

<CULPRIT>
The Stage Manager (name not given in the story)
</CULPRIT>

<EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>
Earlier in the day the stage manager placed the two identical suitcases in the prop closet: one with real money, one with the fake green paper.  Knowing exactly which was which, he waited for the moment when the floor camera was aimed away and the cameraman’s attention lapsed.  In that brief gap he stepped into the closet, grabbed only the money-filled case (no need to open either, because he already knew the correct one), slipped out in under two seconds, and hurried it to his car trunk in the parking lot.  He then returned to work as if nothing had happened, confident that the identical prop suitcase would not be missed until the last minute, when chaos would reign.  
When show time approached, the missing case was discovered.  Police were called, suspects were gathered, and alibis checked.  The key clue—only the person who already knew which suitcase held the cash could have acted so quickly—pointed straight at the stage manager, and a search of his car revealed the stolen $10,000.
</EVENT RECONSTRUCTION>

<WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
• Mr Green arrived after the camera had already recorded the single quick entry into the closet; he had no opportunity.  
• Dusty wore a leotard—no pant legs—and was visible to others most of the time; the camera recorded a trouser-leg.  She also did not know which suitcase held the real money.  
• Bumbo was in full costume in his dressing room, confirmed by the narrator and by a later search; he lacked the time window and would likewise have had to open both cases to find the cash.  
• The narrator was either talking with Bumbo or being escorted by police during the critical interval and never knew which suitcase was which.  
Hence only the stage manager had motive, knowledge, opportunity, and was caught with the loot.
</WHY THE OTHER SUSPECTS ARE INNOCENT>
